body:
Hey @Eriz11 

Thanks for the issue. Tagging the author @akwon31.

Hi @Eriz11 

The weights displayed for ``2019-05-26`` in the final ``all_weights`` is actually the weights predicted from data until ``2019-05-25``. Therefore, if we had ``{A:0.25, B:0.25, C:0.5}`` for ``2019-05-26``, it actually means based on the data until ``2019-05-25`` we decided to choose those weights for the day's start. The final returns are calculated from the change in daily returns for each portfolio. Also calling ``.weights`` gives you the most recent prediction based on the entire data.

To your first observation of calling ``.allocate()`` on the whole dataset for the last price, it is necessary to do that if the particular algorithm looks back for the whole duration (i.e. CORN, OLMAR-2, etc).

To your second observation, that should be a lot faster, but it does depend on which one you are choosing. ``RMR`` in particular does have its specific window frame, so as long as you input the correct number of data points and initial weight, it should be fine. However, for the CORN strategies, it is based on the entire historical window, so that might not be the best choice.

For *PD*, I think what you've done in *1* and *2* are perfectly valid to recalculate and append the results, but for *PD2*, I'm slightly reluctant to do so as simulating can be in different forms especially with different transaction costs considerations (something that I have not incorporated).

Thanks for pointing out these things, I should clarify these issues in the docs.

Hey @akwon31 !

Many thanks for the rapid response!

> The weights displayed for 2019-05-26 in the final all_weights is actually the weights predicted from data until 2019-05-25. Therefore, if we had {A:0.25, B:0.25, C:0.5} for 2019-05-26, it actually means based on the data until 2019-05-25 we decided to choose those weights for the day's start. The final returns are calculated from the change in daily returns for each portfolio. Also calling .weights gives you the most recent prediction based on the entire data.

So, let's say that today `2020-06-26` after the close of X market I get all the `close` data up to and including today, input that into the `.allocate()` method (_without taking into account here that I could optimize the algorithm by just passing the `window` data for some implementations_) and the `.weights` attribute would be the weights that are chosen for `Monday start` in this case (i.e. `2020-06-29`).

If my assumption and understanding is correct (**correct me again if I'm wrong**), the implementation is even more brilliant and straightforward!

> For PD, I think what you've done in 1 and 2 are perfectly valid to recalculate and append the results, but for PD2, I'm slightly reluctant to do so as simulating can be in different forms especially with different transaction costs considerations (something that I have not incorporated).

Understood. I meant not as a "must" but more like an accesory implementation, but I'm sure that you will have better and more complete ideas for it!

Many thanks again!

@Eriz11 
> So, let's say that today 2020-06-26 after the close of X market I get all the close data up to and including today, input that into the .allocate() method (without taking into account here that I could optimize the algorithm by just passing the window data for some implementations) and the .weights attribute would be the weights that are chosen for Monday start in this case (i.e. 2020-06-29).

This is correct.

One thing to note is that for OLPS, it is assumed that you can buy and sell at the given price for every date, which is most likely unreasonable in any given market.

Hi @Eriz11,

Just want to make double sure there is no confusion. You give it todays close with the expectation that you can execute at todays close, not the next days open. That would not be the correct way to apply the algorithm. 

In practice you pass through the best asks before the closing auction, then place your trades with the expectations that price wont be radically different in the auction.

Hey @Jackal08 ! 

Thanks for joining and for the clarification! 

Got it. Your notes are totally reasonable so that the execution prices don't diverge a lot from the ones just passed to the algorithm.

That even puts more emphasis in the need of the computation being efficient and fast, doesn't it?

Computation time should be reasonable but I don't see it as a blocker. 

The main hurdle I see is selecting a universe of stocks that have the properties that the algorithms try to exploit. 

A smaller universe of the correct stocks is much faster to compute and has a higher PnL.

Hi all,

Thank you for your responses

Would there be a way to add slippage to make the backtest more reasonable?
